Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of ScaleMed: A Platform for Scalable mHealth Research and Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, designing and developing 'ScaleMed', an open-source instrument, aims to accelerate the progression of mHealth technologies from lab prototypes to at-scale clinical trials. The instrument impacts the area of healthcare, currently one of the biggest societal challenges. By providing a streamlined method to include diverse devices, the instrument will make significant contributions to the field. Using open-standards-compliant protocols, ScaleMed will help open doors to new at-scale clinical trials and lower the technology barrier. Since the infrastructure will be open-source and will serve as a community resource, its impact will scale with its user populations. Finally, the educational and outreach plan will certainly have a high impact, in the critical area of mHealth.

The instrument consists of three components: Hardware Adaptor; Medical Application Modules, Libraries and Templates; and Cloud Control and Management. The instrument will be available as open-source to the entire community. Its immediate deployment is foreseen in three mHealth projects currently led by the PIs: SOLVD: a smartphone based tracking systems for conditions of depression; mobileVision, a smartphone based retinal imager; and mobileSpiro, a portable personalized spirometer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Healthcare systems all over the world are bursting at their seams primarily because the systems and protocols concerning healthcare access and delivery do not enjoy the economies of scale that revolutionized other aspects of our life, most notably telecommunications and computing. Mobile health (mHealth) technologies have the potential to leverage upon the scalability, universal access and personalization afforded by smartphones to address the healthcare challenges facing us today. Unfortunately, most of mHealth innovations face similar architectural and structural challenges in making the leap from a lab prototype to clinical practice. As a result, the excitement and optimism about mHealth is yet to make real impact in the lives of people and the cost of healthcare delivery, primarily because clinical evidence collected at-scale remains huge.

In this project, we developed Healthsense, a new platform for scalable clinical trials which can include allow the use mobile phones, off-the-shelf devices, and custom lab devices to enable clinical trials with faster concept to trial times. The platform is designed to be: (i) highly modular structure, allowing us to add new features throughout the platform easily, (ii) cross-platform with remote-reconfigurable iOS and Android apps, (iii) multiple layers of security to ensure data safety, and (iv) a web-based GUI interface that allows the clinical staff members to adapt their trials from a simple interface, and provides analytics on how the participants are using their app. The platform is now in active use and is on track to achieve sustainability by supporting new innovative trials, which can either use the platform as-is or need customizations.

The project involved multiple graduate and undergraduate students, including from under-represented groups. The project members have won numerous awards and internships, and several undergraduate students have chosen to pursue graduate school.
